G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Court’s authority to modify a prior custody and parenting time order derives from G.L. c. 208, § 28, which provides that upon a material and substantial change in circumstances, the Court “may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of the minor children.”

G.L. c. 209C.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C; G.L. c. 215, § 6)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court further has general equity jurisdiction in domestic relations matters concerning the care, custody, maintenance, and support of minor children under G.L. c. 215, § 6.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting time concerning the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and G.L. c. 215, § 6, because the original custody and parenting time judgment was issued by this Court on or about May 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the guiding standard for any order concerning custody and parenting time is the “best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 842; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996).

*Schuh v. Schuh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 502.proposition: Since entry of the 2018 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of the minor child, such that the existing custody and parenting time provisions are no longer appropriate.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 502.support_reasoning: The opinion deals solely with whether federal tax law (26 U.S.C. § 152(e)) prevents a Massachusetts probate judge from allocating federal dependency exemptions between divorced parents. It does not address custody, parenting time, or modification standards such as a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting a child’s welfare. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that there has been a material change in circumstances warranting modification of custody or parenting time provisions after a 2018 judgment.
*Schuh v. Schuh*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 502.relevant_excerpt: "The sole issue raised by the wife’s appeal is whether the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 which amended 26 U.S.C. § 152(e)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code precludes a State judge from allocating dependency exemptions for children of divorced or separated parents. The judgment entered by the probate judge in this case allocated six of the couple’s exemptions to the husband, the noncustodial parent."

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting time order “may be modified if the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, § 28; see also *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150 (2015).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case under G.L. c. 208, § 30, focusing on whether removal is in the children’s best interests and on the “cause shown” standard. It does not articulate or apply the separate G.L. c. 208, § 28 standard that a custody or parenting time order may be modified only upon a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests. The quoted pages discuss the best‑interests analysis for removal with joint physical custody, not the § 28 modification test, so the case does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183\u.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents … shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: Massachusetts law provides that a custody or parenting time order “may be modified if the court finds that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, § 28; see also *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177, 183–84 (2006); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150 (2015).
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Murray deals with a removal request under G.L. c. 208, § 30 and a child support modification; it does not articulate the general standard for modifying a custody or parenting time order under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The only mention of § 28 is in a footnote concerning the standard for modifying child support (inconsistency with the Guidelines), not a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ plus best interests test for custody/parenting time. Thus, Murray does not provide direct authority for the proposition cited.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 2011, c. 93, § 37, provides that a child support order shall be modified ‘if there is an inconsistency between the amount of the existing order and the amount that would result from application of the child support guidelines.’ Although the father alleged that there had been a material change of circumstances, the judge here was correct to apply those guidelines to the parties’ updated financial circumstances.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262–63 (2001) (modification supported by changes in living situation and child’s adjustment).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: A parent’s improved and appropriate housing for the child is a material change relevant to custody and parenting time. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 262–63 (2001) (modification supported by changes in living situation and child’s adjustment).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does treat changes in the child’s living situation (including housing and neighborhood environment) as relevant to the removal/custody analysis and recognizes that the mother’s move to a safer, more appropriate home in Providence improved both her and the child’s quality of life. However, the court ultimately holds that there was no material and substantial change supporting a transfer of custody, so the case is more about removal and overall quality of life than a clear holding that improved housing alone constitutes a material change for custody modification. It still provides some support for the proposition by recognizing better living conditions as a significant factor in the best‑interests analysis.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “That there were improvements in Caleb’s quality of life as a result of the move is amply supported by the uncontroverted evidence. While living in Shrewsbury the mother worked at several part-time jobs to make ends meet, in addition to commuting one hour each way to Rhode Island. This impaired the amount of time she had to spend with Caleb. Caleb lived with his mother in a small basement apartment in an apartment complex in Shrewsbury that had no playground and few children of Caleb’s age… By contrast, the move to Rhode Island reduced the mother’s commute to five minutes and she was able to quit most of her part-time jobs, giving her more time to spend with Caleb.”}

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The nature and quality of the parent‑child relationship, as well as the child’s increasing age and evolving needs, constitute a material change that warrants reconsideration of the parenting schedule. See *Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704, 711–12 (1985) (best interests turn on child’s relationship with each parent and the child’s adjustment); *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. at 151–52 (changes in child’s needs and relationships since prior judgment relevant to modification).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: Yannas does discuss best interests in terms of the child’s quality of life, relationships, and adjustment, but it does so in the context of an initial custody/removal determination under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not in a post‑judgment modification setting. The opinion does not hold or suggest that changes in the nature and quality of the parent‑child relationship or in the child’s age and evolving needs constitute a ‘material change’ warranting reconsideration of a parenting schedule. Using Yannas as authority for the quoted ‘material change’ proposition therefore overreads its holding and misplaces its context.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (child’s preference may be considered where child has reached an appropriate age and maturity).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: While the child’s wishes are not controlling, Massachusetts law recognizes that the Court may consider a reasonably mature child’s preferences as one factor among many in determining best interests. See *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (child’s preference may be considered where child has reached an appropriate age and maturity); *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616–17 (1987) (similar).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Bouchard focuses solely on the requirement that custody determinations be based on the child’s welfare and that all relevant best‑interest factors be weighed. It says nothing about considering a reasonably mature child’s custodial preferences or the child’s wishes at all. Therefore, this opinion excerpt does not support the specific proposition that a mature child’s preferences may be considered as a factor in determining best interests.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. 555, 556 n.5 (1980). The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.proposition: While the child’s wishes are not controlling, Massachusetts law recognizes that the Court may consider a reasonably mature child’s preferences as one factor among many in determining best interests. See *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981) (child’s preference may be considered where child has reached an appropriate age and maturity); *Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616–17 (1987) (similar).
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that the preference of a ten‑year‑old child is “a factor to be considered” but “not given decisive weight,” and it cites earlier Massachusetts custody cases in support. That aligns with the proposition that a reasonably mature child’s wishes are not controlling but may be considered as one factor among many in the best‑interests analysis.
*Bak v. Bak*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 616.relevant_excerpt: “Tony’s custody presents a closer question. His father appears to have indoctrinated him with some dislike for his mother, and he has expressed a preference for Bielefeld. … The preference of someone Tony’s age (ten at the time of the proceedings) is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Dumain v. Gwynne, 10 Allen 270, 275 (1865); Stone v. Duffy, 219 Mass. 178, 182 (1914); Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 601-602 (1981); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 713 (1985); Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812, 820 (1981).”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.raw_text: *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (emotional well‑being and continuity of care are central to best‑interests analysis).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.proposition: The minor child’s stated wish to spend more overnight time with Mother, combined with the therapeutic evidence that the child feels distress and guilt over limited time with Mother, are material, post‑judgment developments bearing directly on the child’s well‑being and best interests. See *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843–44 (2003) (emotional well‑being and continuity of care are central to best‑interests analysis).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.support_reasoning: The quoted pages of Custody of Kali focus on defining and operationalizing the ‘best interests of the child’ standard, emphasizing stability, continuity of care, and maintaining existing satisfactory custodial arrangements. They do not discuss a child’s post‑judgment wishes, therapeutic evidence of distress or guilt, or what constitutes a material post‑judgment change. While the case supports the general proposition that emotional well‑being and continuity of care are central to best‑interests analysis, it does not provide authority for treating a child’s later‑expressed desire for more time with one parent and related therapeutic evidence as a material, post‑judgment development.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843\u2.relevant_excerpt: “These efforts also reflect the view that it is in the ‘best interests of the child’ to preserve the current placement with a parent, if it is a satisfactory one, and that stability and continuity with the child’s primary caregiver is itself an important factor in a child’s successful upbringing… If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement… Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child.” (439 Mass. at 842–43).

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the guiding standard for any order concerning custody and parenting time is the “best interests of the child.” G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. at 842; *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.support_reasoning: The opinion does not contain an express, general statement that "the guiding standard for any order concerning custody and parenting time is the best interests of the child," nor does it cite G.L. c. 208, § 31 in that precise formulation. However, the court’s analysis assumes and applies the best-interests standard in reviewing and remanding the custody order, focusing on how domestic violence must be considered in determining the appropriateness of the custody award for the child. In this way, the case is consistent with, and functionally supportive of, the proposition even though it is not the clearest direct citation for that exact phrasing.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590, 595.relevant_excerpt: Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance. Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking.

*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the need to consider the children’s best interests and criticizes the trial judge for not addressing specific placement options, including the importance of sibling relationships and keeping children within the natural family. However, it does not set out, adopt, or list the multi-factor best-interests test described in the proposition (age, relationship with each parent, capacity to provide, home stability, effect of changes, preference). Its best-interests discussion is narrower and focused mainly on sibling relationships and family placement, so it does not provide authority for the full factor list claimed.
*Care & Protection of Three Minors*, 392.relevant_excerpt: “This court has said that the ‘parental fitness’ test and the ‘best interests of the child’ test are not mutually exclusive, but rather ‘reflect different degrees of emphasis on the same factors.’ … In this case, the judge’s task was not complete once he had determined that the mother should not have custody of her children. Also, he should have addressed the various placement options which would further the children’s best interests… The judge’s findings in this case are deficient in that he failed to address two issues: the importance of the sibling relationship, and whether placement of all three children with the paternal grandparents would be in the best interests of the children.”
